sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 31/2100Z
sections.text: TO 01/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 6993 (S09E55) PRODUCED AN M5/1F FLARE WITH ASSOCIATED TYPE II AND IV SWEEPS AT 01/0349Z. THIS REGION ALSO GENERATED AN M3/1N FLARE AT 01/1129Z. THIS AREA IS STACKED ABOVE REGION 6994 (S15E62) WHICH IS LARGER AND MORE COMPLEX, BUT HAS PRODUCED ONLY ISOLATED SUBFLARING. REGION 6988 (S15W36) SHOWED SOME GROWTH TODAY WHILE PRODUCING SEVERAL M-CLASS FLARES. AN M2/2B FLARE FROM THIS AREA AT 01/2024Z WAS FOLLOWED BY AN M5/1N FLARE ERUPTING IN REGION 6985 (S17W55) AT 01/2036Z. IT IS APPARENT THAT REGION 6988 CONTRIBUTED SOMEWHAT TO 6985'S M5 X-RAY EVENT. A MAJOR TYPE II SWEEP AND 610 FLUX UNIT TENFLARE BURST ACCOMPANIED THIS LATEST M5 FLARE. NO NEW REGIONS WERE ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. CONTINUED M-CLASS FLARING IS POSSIBLE FROM REGIONS 6985, 6988, AND THE 6993/6994 COMPLEX.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 31/2100Z TO 01/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN MOSTLY QUIET TO UNSETTLED.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE AT THE START OF THE PERIOD IN RESPONSE TO FLARING NOTED ON THE 30TH. A WELL POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE MAY AFFECT THE FIELD ON THE 4TH.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 01/2100Z
sections.text: TO 02/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 6994 (S15E49) PRODUCED AN M1/SF FLARE AT 02/1224Z. THIS AREA CONTINUED TO GROW IN SIZE AND COMPLEXITY THROUGH THE PERIOD. REGION 6993 (S09E43), STACKED TO THE NORTH OF 6994, ALSO SHOWED SOME GROWTH WHILE GENERATING ISOLATED C-CLASS FLARES. REGIONS 6985 (S17W66) AND 6988 (S15W48) EACH PRODUCED OCCASIONAL C-CLASS EVENTS. SPOT GROWTH WAS NOTED IN THE TRAILING PORTION OF 6985 WHERE SOME OF THE FLARING HAS BEEN NOTED. TWO 10 DEGREE SEGMENTS OF FILAMENT, ONE LOCATED NEAR S18E10, THE OTHER NEAR S25W35, DISAPPEARED DURING THE LAST 24 HOURS. NEW REGION 6966 (N08E76) WAS ASSIGNED.

sections.text: GENERALLY MODERATE. REGIONS 6985, 6988, AND THE 6993/6994 COMPLEX MAY PRODUCE ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARES.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE THE FIRST TWO DAYS IN RESPONSE TO A CORONAL HOLE AND POSSIBLE EFFECTS FROM MAJOR FLARING NOTED ON THE 1ST.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 02/2100Z
sections.text: TO 03/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 6993 (S09E30) PRODUCED THREE M1 X-RAY FLARES. ONE OF WHICH WAS A LONG DURATION EVENT PEAKING AT 1716Z. AN M3/1N FLARE ERUPTED IN REGION 6994 (S16E36) AT 0943Z. THIS AREA REMAINED HOT DURING MOST OF THE PERIOD WITH SOME GROWTH NOTED. REGION 6988 (S14W59) REMAINED GENERALLY QUIET. REGION 6985 (S18W78) ALSO SHOWED LITTLE ACTION. AN UNCORRELATED C7 X-RAY EVENT AT 0717Z WAS ACCOMPANIED BY A WEAK TYPE II RADIO SWEEP. NEW REGIONS 6997 (S21E37) AND 6998 (N03E69) WERE ASSIGNED. 6997 IS STACKED SOUTH OF 6994 AND MAY PROVIDE ADDITIONAL INTERACTION IN THIS ALREADY COMPLEX AREA.

sections.text: MODERATE. ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARING REMAINS POSSIBLE FROM REGIONS 6985, 6988, 6993, AND 6994.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 03/2100Z
sections.text: TO 04/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 6993 (S10E18), THOUGH SHOWING LITTLE GROWTH OR INCREASED COMPLEXITY, PRODUCED FOUR M-CLASS FLARES. THE LARGEST WAS AN M2/1N AT 0539Z. REGION 6994 (S15E23) CONTINUED TO GROW IN SIZE, BUT REMAINED GENERALLY QUIET. ISOLATED SUBFLARING WAS OBSERVED FROM REGION 6985 (S20W90). REGION 6988 (S14W70) GENERATED THE LARGEST EVENT OF THE PERIOD: AN M4/1N FLARE AT 1846Z. A 290 FLUX UNIT TENFLARE BURST ACCOMPANIED THIS ACTIVITY. AN UNCORRELATED LONG DURATION M1 X-RAY EVENT WAS OBSERVED AT 1129Z. NEW REGIONS 6998 (N03E57), 6999 (N21E66), AND 7000 (N13W27) WERE ASSIGNED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. CONTINUED M-CLASS FLARING IS POSSIBLE FROM REGIONS 6985, 6988, 6993, AND 6994.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN MOSTLY QUIET TO UNSETTLED. A SATELLITE LEVEL PROTON ENHANCEMENT AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV BEGAN NEAR 04/0300Z AND CONTINUED THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD. A TENTATIVE PEAK OF 1.6 PFU WAS NOTED AT 1240Z.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY UNSETTLED. THE PROTON ENHANCEMENT SHOULD DECLINE TO BACKGROUND LEVELS WITHIN THE NEXT 24 HOURS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 06/2100Z
sections.text: TO 07/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 6994 (S16W17) PRODUCED THE TWO M-CLASS EVENTS OF THE INTERVAL, AN M1/0N AT 0415Z AND AN M1/0F AT 1457Z. THE REGION IS STILL COMPLEX MAGNETICALLY AND CONTINUES TO EVOLVE IN WHITE LIGHT. NEARBY REGION 6993 (S10W22) HAD FEW FLARES AS IT SLOWLY DECAYED. NEW EMERGING REGIONS CAUSED THE 10.7 CM RADIO FLUX TO INCREASE FROM YESTERDAY AS SIX NEW REGIONS WERE ASSIGNED. THE NEW ARRIVALS ARE REGIONS 7002 (N08W51), 7003 (N16E26), 7004 (S16E09), 7005 (N21E11), 7006 (N10E19), AND 7007 (S05E81). REGION 7003 SEEMS TO BE THE BRIGHTEST OF THE LOT.

sections.text: PERSIST AT MODERATE LEVELS. REGION 6994, STILL THE PREMIER ACTIVE CENTER, SHOULD GENERATE OCCASIONAL M-CLASS FLARES. REGIONS 6993 AND NEWLY ASSIGNED 7003, THOUGH LESS CAPABLE, MAY MUSTER AN ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENT.

sections.text: MODERATE. REGION 6994 IS THE PRIME CANDIDATE FOR ISOLATED M-CLASS ACTIVITY. OTHER REGIONS OF INTEREST MAY BE 6993, 7002, AND 7007.

sections.text: TO 09/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 6994 (S17W43) HAD JUST ONE M-CLASS FLARE, BUT THAT WAS AN M5/1N AT 1245Z. SMALL RADIO BURSTS AT FREQUENCIES ACROSS THE SPECTRUM WERE REPORTED WITH THE FLARE. THE REGION SEEMS TO BE SLOWLY DECAYING, BUT RETAINS THE ABILITY TO PRODUCE ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARES. ELSEWHERE, JUST OCCASIONAL SUBFLARES WERE REPORTED, THE LARGEST OF THESE A C5/1F FROM REGION 7007 (S05E54).

sections.text: TO 10/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. VERY FEW FLARES OF ANY MAGNITUDE WERE REPORTED DURING THE DAY AND REGION 6994 (S15W58), THE SITE OF A MAJOR FLARE YESTERDAY, HAD NO ASSOCIATED FLARES. A GENERAL STATE OF DECAY PREVAILED ACROSS THE VISIBLE DISK AS EVIDENCED BY THE LARGE DROP IN THE BACKGROUND 10.7 CM. RADIO FLUX. NO NEW REGIONS WERE ASSIGNED.

sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. REGION 6994 MAY STILL MUSTER AN ISOLATED SMALL M-CLASS EVENT. REGIONS 6996 (N09W31) AND 7007 (S05E41) MAY PRODUCE A SURPRISE EVENT IF FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OCCURS.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS THE PAST 24 HOURS. A SUDDEN IMPULSE MEASURING 23 NANOTESLA AT BOULDER OCCURRED AT 09/2153Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO START THE PERIOD. THE FIELD SHOULD BECOME INCREASINGLY MORE DISTURBED THEREAFTER AS EFFECTS FROM A RECURRENT CORONAL HOLE ARE DUE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 10/2100Z
sections.text: TO 11/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 7004 (S14W44) PRO- DUCED TODAY'S ONLY X-RAY EVENT: A C3/SF AT 0426Z. THIS GROUP SHOWED SOME GROWTH DURING THE PERIOD. NEW REGION 7008 (S05E74) ROTATED INTO VIEW TODAY AS A SMALL D-TYPE GROUP AND SHOWED FAIR- LY BRIGHT PLAGE BUT COULD ONLY PRODUCE ONE SUBFLARE. REGION 6994 (S16W71) CONTINUES AS THE LARGEST GROUP ON THE DISK BUT WAS QUIET AND SHOWED STEADY DECAY. REGION 7007 (S04E28) IS ALSO A FAIRLY LARGE MATURE GROUP BUT WAS STABLE DURING THE PERIOD.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. THERE IS A POSSIBILITY FOR ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENTS FROM EITHER OF 6994 AND 7007 GIVEN THEIR STATE OF DEVELOPMENT. REGION 7004 MIGHT ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO ACTIVITY AS IT CONTINUES TO GROW. AN OVERALL DOWNWARD TREND IN AC- TIVITY AND BACKGROUND LEVELS IS EXPECTED OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS AS REGIONS 6994 AND 6993 ROTATE ACROSS WEST LIMB.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 10/2100Z TO 11/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. AN INITIALLY QUIET TO UNSETTLED FIELD ATTAINED ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS AROUND 1030Z AND STAYED THERE FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD. THE MOST PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE INCREASE WAS THE M5 FLARE OF 09 JANUARY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE GENERALLY ACTIVE OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS. SOME MINOR STORM PERIODS MAY BE EXPECTED AT HIGH LATITUDES ON THE FIRST DAY. THE FORECAST IS BASED ON AN EXPECTATION OF PERSIST- ANCE OF CURRENT ACTIVITY AND ON THE BEGINNING OF EFFECTS FROM A CORONAL HOLE WHICH IS ROTATING INTO A FAVORABLE POSITION FOR GEOMAGNETIC EFFECTS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY ACTIVE WITH SOME HIGH LATITUDE MINOR STORMING OVER THE NEXT TWO DAYS. THIS ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO RESULT FROM A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE. CONDITIONS SHOULD DECREASE TO GENERALLY UNSETTLED LEVELS BY THE THIRD DAY.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 12/2100Z
sections.text: TO 13/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. AN M2 X-RAY EVENT WAS OBSERVED AT 1734Z ACCOMPANIED BY MODEST RADIO BURSTS. THE EVENT WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A LOOP PROMINENCE SYSTEM ON WEST LIMB AT S18 IN THE VICINITY OF REGION 6994 (S16W87). AN M1 X-RAY EVENT WAS OBSERVED LATER AT 1913Z. THIS EVENT DID NOT HAVE AN OBVIOUS SOURCE, ALTHOUGH A BRIGHT POINT WAS OBSERVED ON THE EAST LIMB NEAR S10 DURING THE EVENT. THE LOCATION SUGGESTS THAT OLD REGION 6982 (S13, L-142, DUE BACK TOMORROW) MAY HAVE PRODUCED THE FLARE.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS DURING THE PERIOD. MOST OF THE MINOR STORMING OCCURRED FROM 0300-1200Z. THE REST OF THE ACTIVITY CONSISTED OF OCCASIONAL SPORADIC ACTIVE PERIODS SUPERPOSED ON A QUIET BACKGROUND. THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE FOR THE ACTIVITY IS A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE ACTIVE FOR THE NEXT 24 HOURS. GENERALLY UNSET- TLED LEVELS SHOULD PREVAIL THEREAFTER. A SLIGHT INCREASE MAY OCCUR ON THE THIRD DAY DUE TO EFFECTS FROM ANOTHER CORONAL HOLE WHICH WILL ROTATE TO A FAVORABLE POSITION BY THEN.

sections.text: TO 14/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. AN M1 FLARE OCCURRED AT 1937Z. THE SOURCE WAS FROM BEHIND THE EAST LIMB AT S11. NO SPOTS HAD BEEN OBSERVED AT FORECAST ISSUE TIME, BUT SURGING AND ACTIVE PROMINENCE ACTIVITY WERE NOTED AT THIS LOCATION THROUGH- OUT THE DAY. THE REST OF TODAY'S ACTIVITY CONSISTED OF ONLY A HANDFUL OF LOW LEVEL C-CLASS FLARES. REGIONS 7004 (S15W84) AND 7008 (S09E36) SHOWED THE BRIGHTEST PLAGE OF THE GROUPS ON THE DISK.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. ADDITIONAL ISOLATED M-CLASS ACTIVITY IS POS- SIBLE FROM THE EAST LIMB, AND ALSO FROM EITHER 7007 OR 7008.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 13/2100Z TO 14/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. CONDITIONS WERE MOSTLY UNSETTLED FROM THE START OF THE PERIOD UNTIL ABOUT 1500Z. AT THAT POINT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM COND- ITIONS BEGAN AND CONTINUED THROUGH THE END OF THE PERIOD. THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE IS A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO CONTINUE ACTIVE FOR THE EARLY PART OF THE FIRST DAY, BUT IS EXPECTED TO DECLINE TO GENERALLY UNSETTLED LEVELS BEGINNING SOMETIME TOMORROW AND LASTING THROUGH THE END OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.text: TO 27/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. ONLY ISOLATED C-CLASS FLARING WAS NOTED. MOST OF THESE EVENTS WERE ATTRIBUTED TO REGION 7031 (S04E32) WHICH CONTINUES TO GROW. GROWTH WAS ALSO NOTED IN REGION 7026 (S12W13), 7030 (N07E34), AND 7032 (N07E22). SEVERAL UNCORRELATED L0W-LEVEL C-CLASS EVENTS WERE OBSERVED. THESE MAY HAVE BEEN ASSOCIATED WITH THE NEW REGIONS EMERGING ON THE EASTERN LIMB. NEW REGIONS ASSIGNED INCLUDE 7034 (N08E67), 7035 (S21E74), 7036 (S14E69), 7037 (N06E29) AND 7038 (S12E20).

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. A BRIEF PERIOD OF MINOR STORMING WAS NOTED BETWEEN 27/00-03Z. A SUDDEN IMPULSE MEASURING 14 NANOTESLAS AT BOULDER WAS OBSERVED AT 26/2241Z.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 27/2100Z
sections.text: TO 28/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. ISOLATED C-CLASS FLARING WAS THE EXTENT OF THE PERIOD'S ACTIVITY. REGION 7031 (S05E19) PRODUCED SEVERAL OF THESE FLARES WHILE SHOWING SOME MINOR GROWTH. A C6/1F FLARE WAS OBSERVED FROM REGION 7039 (S16E73) AT 28/1717Z. THIS NEWLY ASSIGNED AREA HAS SHOWN NUMEROUS PLAGE FLUCTUATIONS AND IS LOCATED CLOSE TO THE LIMB WHERE AN ERUPTIVE PROMINENCE WAS NOTED. THE ERUPTION OCCURRED IN CONJUNCTION WITH 7039'S FLARE. REGION 7026 (S13W28) REMAINED GENERALLY QUIET. NEW REGION 7040 (S12W33) WAS ASSIGNED AND IS COMPOSED OF THE SPOT AREA PREVIOUSLY ATTRIBUTED TO THE LEADING PORTION OF 7026.

sections.text: TO 29/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW, HOWEVER A MARKED INCREASE IN FLARING WAS OBSERVED. REGIONS 7031 (S05E05), 7038 (S11W07) AND 7039 (S15E64) EACH CONTRIBUTED SEVERAL C-CLASS FLARES. THE LARGEST, A C9/1F EVENT AT 1544Z, WAS ATTRIBUTED TO 7039. THIS AREA HAS SHOWN NOTABLE GROWTH DURING THE PERIOD. REGION 7038 AND 7031 ALSO DISPLAYED GROWTH. THE LATTER CONTINUES TO REIGN AS THE LARGEST AND MOST COMPLEX ON THE DISK. NEW REGION 7041 (N07E77) WAS ASSIGNED.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 29/2100Z
sections.text: TO 30/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 7031 (S05W08) LEAD THE WAY PRODUCING 3 ENERGETIC EVENTS DURING THE PERIOD. AN M4/2B TENFLARE AT 0939Z AND A LONG DURATION M2/1B FLARE WITH TYPE II AND IV RADIO SWEEPS AT 1954Z WERE THE MOST NOTABLE. THE SWEEPS WERE OF MODERATE INTENSITY AND THE TENFLARE BURST MEASURED 590 SFU. THIS REGION CONTINUED TO SHOW GROWTH IN SIZE WHILE BECOMING INCREASINGLY COMPLEX. REGION 7039 (S14E51) ALSO SHOWED INCREASED SIZE AND COMPLEXITY. AN M1/1F FLARE ERUPTED IN REGION 7026 (S14W52) AT 1400Z. THIS AREA HAS BEEN IN DECLINE DURING THE LAST FEW DAYS. INCREASED GROWTH AND COMPLEXITY WAS NOTED IN REGION 7033 (S11E12) WHICH CONTRIBUTED NUMEROUS SUBFLARES THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD. NEW REGION 7042 (S14E70) WAS ASSIGNED. THIS AREA HAS ALREADY SHOWN SIGNIFICANT ACTIVITY WITH AN M1/SN FLARE AND A LOOP PROMINENCE SYSTEM TO ITS CREDIT.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. MORE M-CLASS FLARES ARE LIKELY WITH REGIONS 7031 AND 7039 PROVIDING THE GREATEST THREAT.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN MOSTLY UNSETTLED.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE ON THE 31ST. ACTIVE TO STORM CONDITIONS ARE POSSIBLE ON 1 FEBRUARY IN RESPONSE TO REGION 7031'S LONG DURATION M2 FLARE. THE FIELD SHOULD RETURN TO MOSTLY UNSETTLED LEVELS BY THE END OF THE PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 30/2100Z
sections.text: TO 31/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7031 (S05W21) HAD THE LARGEST FLARE OF THE DAY, THAT AN M1/1F AT 1917Z. THIS ACTIVITY IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWED A SIMILAR FLARE, AN M1/1N AT 1903Z, IN NEARBY REGION 7032 (N06W28). FREQUENT SUBFLARES WERE OBSERVED THE REST OF THE DAY FROM A VARIETY OF REGIONS, ALTHOUGH REGION 7031 WAS THE MOST PRODUCTIVE. SEVENTEEN REGIONS ARE NOW ON THE VISIBLE DISK, WITH THE NEWEST ONE BEING REGION 7044 (S27E67). TODAY'S 10.7 CM RADIO FLUX EXCEEDED THE 300 MARK.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS THE NEXT 24 HOURS, DUE TO EFFECTS FROM THE LONG DURATION M2 FLARE FROM REGION 7031 ON 30 JANUARY. UNSETTLED TO MILDLY ACTIVE CONDITIONS SHOULD END THE INTERVAL.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE THE NEXT 24 HOURS. STRICTLY UNSETTLED CONDITIONS SHOULD PREVAIL THE LATTER PART OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 01/2100Z
sections.text: TO 02/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7042 (S12E39) GENERATED AN M2/1N FLARE WITH WEAK TYPE II SWEEP AT 0908Z. THE ONLY OTHER M-CLASS EVENT OF THE PERIOD WAS AN M1/0N AT 1520Z FROM REGION 7031 (S05W49). THIS PAIR OF REGIONS DOMINATED THE FLARE ACTIVITY DURING THE PERIOD, AS BOTH WERE LARGELY UNCHANGED IN THEIR APPEARANCE FROM YESTERDAY. BRIGHT PLAGE AND TIGHT MAGNETIC GRADIENTS CHARACTERIZE BOTH GROUPS.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. WATCH PREVIOUSLY MENTIONED REGIONS 7031 AND 7042 FOR ADDITIONAL M-CLASS ACTIVITY. ALSO, REGION 7039 (S15E11) MAY HAVE M-CLASS FLARES TOO, IF AN INSTABILITY DEVELOPS THERE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 01/2100Z TO 02/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS AT MOSTLY ACTIVE LEVELS THE PAST 24 HOURS. EPISODES OF MINOR STORM CONDITIONS OCCURRED AT ALL LATITUDES. THIS DISTURBANCE, BEGINNING ABOUT 01/1500Z, IS LIKELY DUE TO FLARE ACTIVITY OF 30 JANUARY. A RECENT SHOCK, EVIDENCED BY A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 34 NANOTESLA AT BOULDER AT 02/1154Z, MAY BE PROLONGING THE INITIAL FLARE-RELATED PULSE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO VARY FROM UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE CONDITIONS FOR THE NEXT 72 HOURS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 02/2100Z
sections.text: TO 03/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7042 (S12E25) HAD FOUR M-CLASS FLARES THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE EVENTS WERE AN M1/1N AT 02/2250Z, AN M1/0N AT 0053Z, AN M1/0N AT 0701Z, AND AN M1/0F AT 1026Z. SMALL RADIO BURSTS WERE RECORDED WITH THREE OF THE FOUR FLARES. THE REGION ALSO PRODUCED NUMEROUS LESSER-SIZED FLARES AS IT GREW TO OVER 900 MILLIONTHS IN WHITE LIGHT AREA AND RETAINED A GOOD DEGREE OF MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY. REGION 7031 (S04W65), ACTIVE THE PAST FEW DAYS, COULD MUSTER BUT C-LEVEL FLARES.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO
sections.text: CONTINUE MODERATE. MORE M-CLASS FLARES ARE ANTICIPATED FROM REGION 7042, AND, TO A LESSER DEGREE, FROM REGION 7031.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 02/2100Z TO 03/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT MOSTLY MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS THE PAST 24 HOURS. THIS IS A CONTINUATION OF THE DISTURBANCE WHICH BEGAN AROUND 1500Z ON 01 FEBRUARY, AND STRENGTHENED YESTERDAY. STRONG SUBSTORMS OCCURRED IN NIGHT- TIME SECTORS. FLARE ACTIVITY ON 30 JANUARY IS THOUGHT TO HAVE SPAWNED THIS MAGNETIC STORM.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MINOR STORM LEVELS THE NEXT 24 HOURS, WITH THE MOST DISTURBED INTERVALS OCCURRING DURING LOCAL NIGHT- TIMES. THE STORM SHOULD WEAKEN WITH TIME AND GIVE WAY TO UNSETTLED CONDITIONS BY 06 FEBRUARY.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 04/2100Z
sections.text: TO 05/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. THERE WERE THREE M-CLASS FLARES TODAY, THE FIRST WAS AN M1/1F AT 0645Z FROM REGION 7030 (N06W81), THE SECOND WAS AN M2/1B FROM REGION 7039 (S15W28) AT 1319Z. THE THIRD WAS THE LARGEST, AN M3 AT 2032Z, AND MOST INTERESTING, BECAUSE ALTHOUGH THERE WAS A SMALL FLARE IN PROGRESS IN REGION 7039, OBSERVERS BELIEVE THE MAJORITY OF THE X-RAYS EMANATED FROM A BRIGHT POINT ON THE SOUTHEAST LIMB NEAR THE LOCATION OF REGION 7031 (S07E89). ADDITIONAL ANALYSIS MAY CONFIRM A LOCATION AT A LATER DATE. NEW REGION 7048 (S04E38) WAS ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.text: CONTINUE AT MODERATE LEVELS THROUGHOUT THE FORECAST PERIOD. REGIONS 7039 AND 7042 (S12W01) ARE THE MOST LIKELY SOURCES OF THIS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 04/2100Z TO 05/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO ACTIVE LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. ACTIVE CONDITIONS WERE OBSERVED AT ALL LATITUDES AT THE END OF THE UT DAY ON 04 FEBRUARY. SINCE THAT TIME CONDITIONS HAVE BEEN QUIET TO UNSETTLED WITH THE EXCEPTION OF 1200Z WHEN HIGH LATITUDES EXPERIENCED A PERIOD OF ACTIVE CONDITIONS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 05/2100Z
sections.text: TO 06/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. TWO MAJOR FLARES OCCURRED TODAY: THE FIRST WAS AN M7/SN AT 0329Z FROM REGION 7030 (N07W93), AND THE SECOND WAS AN M6/1N AT 1859Z FROM REGION 7039 (S14W41).BOTH EVENTS WERE IMPULSIVE. SOMEWHAT MORE IMPRESSIVE WAS A LONG DURATION M4/2B FLARE FROM REGION 7042 (S11W16) WHICH LASTED ABOUT 150 MINUTES. THE M4 FLARE WAS ACCOMPANIED BY MODERATELY STRONG RADIO BURSTS AND A MODERATE TYPE IV SWEEP. ADDITIONAL M-FLARES OCCURRED DURING THE DAY: AN M2/1B AT 1356Z FROM 7048 (S04E24) AND AN M4 AT 2103UT. THE SOURCE FOR THE LATTER APPEARS TO BE 7030 SINCE STRONG SURGING WAS SEEN ON WEST LIMB AT 7030'S LATITUDE DURING THE EVENT. REGION 7042 IS THE MOST IMPRESSIVE LOOKING REGION ON THE DISK, BUT SHOWED DECAY AND FRAGMENTATION DURING THE PAST 24 HOURS. REGION 7039 SHOWS BOTH GROWTH AND DECAY IN VARIOUS PARTS OF THE GROUP AND APPEARS TO BE COMBINING WITH REGION 7035 (S18W52). NOTE: CORRECTION TO YESTERDAY'S REPORT - THE M3 AT 2032Z WAS FROM THE SOUTHWEST LIMB (S07W89), NOT THE SOUTHEAST (S07E89) AS WAS STATED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE WITH A CHANCE FOR ISOLATED MAJOR FLARES OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS. THE DOMINANT REGIONS ARE 7030, 7039, 7042. THE EFFECTIVENESS OF 7030 WILL DECLINE AS IT ROTATES FARTHER AROUND WEST LIMB. REGIONS 7035 (S18W52), 7048 (S04E24) AND NEW REGION 7050 (N13E67 - D-TYPE) ARE ALSO RESPECTABLE AND COULD CONTRIBUTE TO MODERATE LEVELS OF ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 05/2100Z TO 06/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS QUIET TO UNSETTLED.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE QUIET TO UNSETTLED THROUGH TOMORROW AND PART- WAY THROUGH THE SECOND DAY. AN INCREASE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS AT MID-LATITUDES AND MAJOR STORM LEVELS AT HIGH LATITUDES IS EXPECTED SOMETIME ON THE SECOND DAY. THE DISTURBANCE IS EXPECTED TO LAST THROUGH MOST OF THE THIRD DAY. THIS DISTUR- BANCE IS EXPECTED AS A RESPONSE TO TODAY'S LONG DURATION M4 FLARE FROM REGION 7042.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 06/2100Z
sections.text: TO 07/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE DURING THE LAST 24 HOURS.  REGION 7039 (S14W54) PRODUCED AN M3/2B FLARE THAT MAXED AT 1159Z.  THIS LONG DURATION EVENT WAS ACCOMPANIED BY STRONG TYPE IV RADIO EMISSION AND A MODERATE TYPE II SWEEP. REGION 7039 PRODUCED OTHER SUBFAINT FLARES, AND GREW IN WHITE LIGHT AND H-ALPHA SINCE YESTERDAY.  FOUR NEW REGIONS WERE NUMBERED TODAY.  THEY WERE 7051 (N21E07), 7052 (S21E67), 7053 (S11E74), AND 7054 (N13E75).  STRONG SURGING WAS REPORTED ON BOTH LIMBS.  ON THE WEST LIMB THE DEPARTURE OF REGION 7033 NEAR S13 PRODUCED SURGING TO 0.09 SOLAR RADII, AND SURGING ON THE EAST LIMB OCCURRED NEAR N15 AND S17. FLARE LOOPS WERE ALSO REPORTED NEAR S14E90 BEGINNING AT 1310Z AND ENDING AFTER 1403Z.  A BUSHY, 14-DEGREE-LONG FILAMENT IN THE SOUTHWEST QUADRANT DISAPPEARED BETWEEN 0733-1250Z.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE.  REGIONS 7039 AND 7042 (S12W27) ARE MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX AND ARE CAPABLE OF CONTINUED SIGNIFICANT FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 06/2100Z TO 07/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO ACTIVE LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS.  A SOLAR PROTON ENHANCEMENT THAT BEGAN MID-DAY ON THE 6TH CROSSED EVENT THRESHOLD 07/O645Z.  THE EVENT MAXIMUM WAS 78 PFU AT 1115 AND DECREASED SLOWLY FOR THE REST OF THE DAY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  A GEOMAGNETIC STORM IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO COMMENCE ON 08 FEBRUARY IN RESPONSE THE HIGH LEVELS OF SOLAR ACTIVITY THAT OCCURRED ON 6 FEBRUARY.  THE PEAK OF THE DISTURBANCE IS EXPECTED LATE ON THE 8TH OR EARLY ON THE 9TH, SUBSIDING ON THE 10TH.  THE PROTON EVENT IS EXPECTED TO INTENSIFY WITH THE ARRIVAL OF THE SOLAR WIND SHOCK.  IF NO NEW INJECTIONS OCCUR, THE PRESENT PROTON EVENT SHOULD END BY FEBRUARY 10TH.

sections.text: TO 08/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 7042 (S12W42) PRO- DUCED MOST OF TODAY'S FLARE ACTIVITY INCLUDING THE LARGEST EVENT OF THE PERIOD: A C7/SF AT 0322Z. BOTH REGION 7042 AND 7039 (S15W71) SHOWED CLEAR SIGNS OF DECAY AND SIMPLIFICATION. SOME GROWTH WAS NOTED IN REGIONS 7048 (S04W03) AND 7051 (N21W06) SURGING WAS SEEN ON EAST LIMB AT S17 AND S31.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. REGIONS 7042 AND 7039 CONTINUE TO BE THE MOST LIKELY SOURCES FOR M-CLASS LEVEL FLARES FOR THE NEXT THREE DAYS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 07/2100Z TO 08/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO SEVERE STORM LEVELS. AN INITIALLY QUIET TO ACTIVE FIELD JUMPED UP TO SEVERE STORM LEVELS FOR ABOUT 2 HOURS, FOLLOWING A SUDDEN COMMENCEMENT AT 1429Z (MEASURING 16 GAMMA IN BOULDER). DURING THE DISTURBANCE A MAGNETOPAUSE CROSSING WAS OBSERVED ON GOES-7. SINCE ABOUT 1630Z, HOWEVER, ACTIVITY HAS DECLINED TO GENERALLY ACTIVE LEVELS. THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON EVENT THAT BEGAN AT 07/0645Z ENDED TODAY AT 08/1940UT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS TOMORROW AS A CONTINUATION OF TODAY'S ACTIVITY AND AS ADDITIONAL EFFECTS ARRIVE FROM RECENT MAJOR FLARE ACTIVITY. CONDITIONS SHOULD SUBSIDE TO MOSTLY ACTIVE ON THE SECOND DAY, AND THEN DOWN TO GENERALLY UNSETTLED BY DAY THREE.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE ACTIVE FOR THE FIRST PART OF THE FIRST DAY, AND IS EXPECTED TO DECLINE TO GENERALLY UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 16/2100Z TO 17/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 25 NANOTESLA WAS RECORDED BY THE BOULDER USGS MAGNETOMETER AT 17/0805Z. ACTIVE TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS OCCURRED AT HIGH LATITUDES FROM 17/1500-1800Z. THIS ACTIVITY MAY HAVE BEEN IN RESPONSE TO THE M5/1B FLARE THAT OCCURRED AT 15/2139Z. THE FIELD HAD DECLINED TO QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS BY THE END OF THE PERIOD. A GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON ENHANCEMENT BEGAN NEAR 17/1200Z. THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE WAS THE LONG DURATION M4/2N FLARE MENTIONED ABOVE. THE ENHANCEMENT WAS GRADUALLY DECREASING TOWARD BACKGROUND LEVELS BY THE END OF THE PERIOD.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY ACTIVE DURING THE FIRST TWO DAYS IN RESPONSE TO THE M4/2N FLARE THAT OCCURRED AT 17/0128Z. THE FIELD IS EXPECTED TO SUBSIDE TO MOSTLY UNSETTLED LEVELS DURING THE FINAL DAY.

sections.text: TO 21/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. AN M3 X-RAY EVENT WAS OBSERVED AT 0430Z. A SIGNIFICANT TYPE II SWEEP ACCOMPANIED THIS ACTIVITY ALONG WITH THE REPORT OF A LOOP PROMINENCE SYSTEM IN REGION 7070 (N08E68). NO REPORTS OF FLARING WERE OBTAINED, BUT REGION 7070 APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN THE SOURCE OF THE EVENT. THIS AREA ALSO PRODUCED AN M2/1F FLARE AT 1020Z. REGION 7067 (N05E41) DISPLAYED ONLY ISOLATED SUBFLARING WHILE STILL SHOWING SOME GROWTH. NEW REGIONS 7071 (S06W16), 7072 (S09E69), AND 7073 (S15W37) WERE ASSIGNED.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 21/2100Z
sections.text: TO 22/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7070 (N07E56) PRODUCED AN M2/1F FLARE AT 21/2206Z. THE OPTICAL SIZE OF THE EVENT WAS ESTIMATED AT THE BOULDER OBSERVATORY. LITTLE GROWTH WAS NOTED IN THE REGION, HOWEVER IT IS BECOMING MORE COMPLEX. REGION 7072 (S10E59) PRODUCED A C7/1N FLARE AT 22/1046Z. ISOLATED SUBFLARING WAS OBSERVED IN REGIONS 7067 (N05E28) AND 7071 (S05W32). 7067 DISPLAYED NOTABLE OVERNIGHT GROWTH. A LARGE, 31 DEGREE LONG SEGMENT OF FILAMENT DISAPPEARED BETWEEN 21/2300Z AND 2330Z. THE FILAMENT WAS PART OF A SOLAR SECTOR BOUNDARY WHICH BISECTED REGION 7073 (S15W51), AN AREA THAT EMERGED ALONG THIS BOUNDARY DURING THE LAST 36 HOURS. REGIONS 7074 (N16E70) AND 7075 (N15E17) WERE ASSIGNED TODAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. REGIONS 7070 AND 7076 CONTINUE TO POSE THE GREATEST THREAT FOR M-FLARE PRODUCTION.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE THROUGH THE 24TH. ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM CONDITIONS ARE POSSIBLE BY THE 25TH IN RESPONSE TO EFFECTS FROM THE FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCE NOTED ABOVE.

sections.text: TO 23/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. AN UNCORRELATED C6 X-RAY EVENT WAS OBSERVED AT 22/2119Z. NO FLARING WAS REPORTED WITH THIS ACTIVITY HOWEVER A LOOP PROMINENCE SYSTEM WAS OBSERVED AFTERWARDS IN REGION 7074 (N16E59). ISOLATED SUBFLARING WAS OBSERVED IN REGIONS 7069 (S04E29), 7070 (N07E43), AND 7073 (S15W63). SIGNIFICANT GROWTH AND INCREASED MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY WAS NOTED IN REGIONS 7070 AND 7067 (N05E15). AN EVENT LEVEL BRIGHT SURGE WAS OBSERVED ON THE EAST LIMB NEAR S21 AT 1516Z. A MAJOR TYPE II SWEEP ACCOMPANIED THIS ACTIVITY WHICH MAY BE ASSOCIATED WITH RETURNING OLD REGION 7039 (S14, L-330), A SPOT AREA WHICH PRODUCED SEVERAL SIGNIFICANT FLARES DURING ITS LAST ROTATION.  NEW REGION 7076 (N10E70) WAS ASSIGNED.

sections.text: MODERATE. ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARING REMAINS POSSIBLE FROM REGION 7067 OR 7070. RETURNING OLD REGION 7039 MAY ADD TO ACTIVITY LEVELS.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN QUIET TO UNSETTLED.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 24/2100Z
sections.text: TO 25/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7070 (N07E14) PRODUCED THE ONLY M-CLASS FLARE OF THE PERIOD, AN M4/2B PARALLEL RIBBON EVENT AT 24/2335Z. RADIO BURSTS INCLUDED A TENFLARE OF 450 SFU AS WELL AS A TYPE IV SWEEP THAT WAS REPORTED TO LAST AT LEAST 4 HOURS. THE REGION IS NOW MEASURED TO BE 600 MILLIONTHS IN WHITE LIGHT AREA, AND HAVE A MODERATE DEGREE OF MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY. ELSEWHERE, VERY FEW FLARES WERE REPORTED FROM THE OTHER 12 SPOTTED REGIONS. ONE NEW REGION, 7079 (S14W55), WAS BORN ON THE DISK.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. REGION 7070 IS A GOOD CANDIDATE FOR ADDITIONAL M- CLASS FLARES, AND REGION 7067 (N04W11), THE LARGEST REGION NOW VISIBLE, MAY OFFER AN M-CLASS EVENT TOO.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 24/2100Z TO 25/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT PREDOMINANTLY MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE DISAPPEARANCE OF A LARGE FILAMENT ON FEBRUARY 22ND IS THE LIKELY CAUSE OF THE ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE LEVELS FOR THE NEXT 24 HOURS. THIS PERIOD OF RELATIVE CALM SHOULD BE BRIEF AS EFFECTS FROM THE M4/2B FLARE OF 24/2335Z ARE DUE THE LAST 2 DAYS OF THE INTERVAL WHEN MINOR STORM LEVELS SHOULD PREVAIL.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 25/2100Z
sections.text: TO 26/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7073, NOW ALMOST A DAY PAST WEST LIMB NEAR S16, HAD THE ONE M-CLASS FLARE OF THE INTERVAL, AN IMPULSIVE M1/0N AT 0139Z. SURGING HAS BEEN REPORTED IN THAT AREA SINCE. LITTLE ELSE OF SIGNIFICANCE HAS OCCURRED ON THE DISK TODAY, AS MOST REGIONS HAVE BEEN STABLE OR SLOWLY DECAYING. ONE NEW REGION WAS ASSIGNED, 7080 (N20W11).

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO
sections.text: CONTINUE MODERATE. ALTHOUGH UNPRODUCTIVE LATELY, REGIONS 7067 (N05W26) AND 7070 (N07E01) ARE LIKELY SOURCES FOR ISOLATED M-CLASS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 25/2100Z TO 26/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD FLUCTUATED BETWEEN UNSETTLED AND MAJOR STORM LEVELS THE PAST 24 HOURS. A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 20 NANO- TESLA (AT BOULDER) OCCURRED AT 1657Z, HERALDING THE ONSET OF MINOR TO MAJOR STORM CONDITIONS AT ALL LATITUDES. THE GOES 6 AND 7 SPACECRAFT EXPERIENCED MAGNETOPAUSE CROSSINGS, LASTING MORE THAN THREE HOURS, JUST AFTER 1700Z. THIS DISTURBANCE IS PROBABLY DUE TO THE QUICK ARRIVAL OF A SHOCK FROM THE M4/2B FLARE OF 24/2335Z. ANOTHER EFFECT OF THIS FLARE IS AN ORDER OF MAGNITUDE INCREASE IN THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON FLUX WHICH BEGAN EARLY ON THE 26TH. THE PEAK FLUX SO FAR IS ABOUT 1 PFU.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS THE NEXT 24 TO 36 HOURS. THE DISTURBANCE SHOULD GRADUALLY WEAKEN, WITH UNSETTLED CONDITIONS IN PLACE BY 29 FEBRUARY. THE CURRENT PROTON ENHANCEMENT IS ALSO EXPECTED TO DECLINE THROUGHOUT THE PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 26/2100Z
sections.text: TO 27/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 7070 (N07W12) PRODUCED A SURPRISING X3/3B TENFLARE AT 0956Z. ASSOCIATED RADIO INCLUDED A BURST OF 8,300 SFU AT 2695 MHZ, AND BOTH TYPES II AND IV SWEEP. THIS FLARE WAS UNCHARACTERISTICALLY LARGE FOR THIS REGION, GIVEN THE SIZE AND FREQUENCY OF ITS RECENT FLARE OUTPUT. HOWEVER, PRIOR TO THIS EVENT IT DID YIELD AN M1/1N FLARE AT 26/2342Z. THE REGION HAS BEEN VERY QUIET SINCE THE MAJOR FLARE, BUT SEEMS TO RETAIN TIGHT MAGNETIC GRADIENTS ALONG A SHEARED EAST-WEST NEUTRAL LINE. OTHER ACTIVITY DURING THE INTERVAL INCLUDED AN EPL FROM S43W90 AT 0739Z.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 7070 IS THE BEST CANDIDATE FOR FLARE ACTIVITY IN THE NEXT THREE DAYS. VECTOR MAGNETOGRAM DATA INDICATE THE REGION HAS NOT SIMPLIFIED SINCE THE X3/3B FLARE EARLIER TODAY. THEREFORE, WATCH FOR INFREQUENT BUT STRONG FLARES FROM THIS SITE. ALSO, REGION 7067 (N04W40) IS DUE FOR ITS OWN ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 26/2100Z TO 27/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT MOSTLY MINOR STORM LEVELS THE PAST 24 HOURS. A FORBUSH DECREASE BEGAN EARLY IN THE INTERVAL AND IS IN PROGRESS. NEUTRON COUNTS ARE APPROXIMATELY 9 PERCENT BELOW NORMAL. THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON ENHANCEMENT WAS FURTHER FUELED BY THE X3 FLARE, REACHING FLUXES JUST SHY OF THE 10 PFU REQUIRED FOR A FORMAL EVENT. SLOW DECAY IS EVIDENT IN THE PROTONS AT THIS TIME.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO PERSIST AT MINOR STORM LEVELS THE NEXT 24 HOURS. ANOTHER SHOCK, THIS FROM THE X3 FLARE, IS EXPECTED EARLY ON 29 FEBRUARY. MINOR TO SEVERE STORM CONDITIONS SHOULD SOON FOLLOW THE SHOCK'S ARRIVAL AND LINGER THROUGH THE END OF THE FORECAST PERIOD. THE CURRENT FORBUSH DECREASE SHOULD CONTINUE THE NEXT FEW DAYS. THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON ENHANCEMENT COULD GO EITHER WAY. MORE M OR X CLASS FLARES FROM REGION 7070 COULD EASILY DRIVE THE FLUXES INTO EVENT LEVEL. IF NO MORE SIGNIFICANT FLARES OCCUR, THE FLUXES SHOULD CONTINUE THEIR SLOW DECLINE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 29/2100Z
sections.text: TO 01/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. ONLY A FEW C-CLASS FLARES OCCURRED DURING THE DAY. NEWLY NUMBERED REGION 7083 (S10W62) PRODUCED THE LARGEST OF THESE: A C5/SN AT 1632Z. THIS GROUP SHOWED GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT DURING THE DAY. REGION 7070 (N07W54) CONTINUED AS THE LARGEST, MOST COMPLEX GROUP ON THE DISK BUT DIDN'T PRODUCE ANY FLARES AND SHOWED SIGNS OF SLOW DECAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. THE MOST LIKELY SOURCES FOR M-CLASS ACTIVITY ARE 7067 (N03W81), 7070, AND 7083

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 29/2100Z TO 01/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS. YESTERDAY'S MINOR STORM CONTINUED THROUGH 1200Z, WITH A BRIEF QUIET LULL FROM 0000-0300Z. THE PEAK OF THE STORM FOR LAST 24 HOURS ACTIVITY OCCURRED FROM 0600-1200Z, WITH MINOR STORM LEVELS AT MID-LATITUDES AND MAJOR STORM LEVELS AT HIGH LATITUDES. THE ACTIVITY DROPPED DOWN TO QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS AFTER 1200Z AND REMAINED THERE THROUGH THE END OF THE PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE GENERALLY UNSETTLED TOMORROW. AN INCREASE TO MOSTLY ACTIVE IS EXPECTED, BEGINNING ON THE SECOND DAY AND LASTING PARTWAY THROUGH THE THIRD DAY. THE INCREASE IS EXPECTED AS A RESPONSE TO A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BECOME ACTIVE SOMETIME TOMORROW AND THE DISTURBANCE SHOULD LAST PART WAY THROUGH THE SECOND DAY. THIS ACTIVITY IS DUE TO A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE. CONDITIONS SHOULD BECOME QUIET TO UNSETTLED AGAIN BY LATE ON DAY TWO AND ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE AT THESE LEVELS THROUGHOUT THE REMAINDER OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 06/2100Z
sections.text: TO 07/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 7093 (S24E67) PRODUCED THE LARGEST FLARE OF THE PAST DAY, A C5/SF AT 07/ 0213Z. REGION 7091 (S09E57) ALSO PRODUCED LOW LEVEL C-CLASS ACTIVITY. THE ACTIVE REGIONS CURRENTLY ON THE DISK ARE RELATIVELY SMALL. REGION 7091 IS POSSIBLY THE MOST COMPLEX AND IS LOCATED IN THE DECAYING MAGNETIC FIELDS OF OLD REGION 7056. THREE SMALL NEW REGIONS WERE NUMBERED- 7094 (N15E65), 7095 (N16W18), AND 7096 (S05E20).

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. ISOLATED M-CLASS ACTIVITY IS POSSIBLE IN REGIONS 7091 AND 7093.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 06/2100Z TO 07/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS QUIET TO UNSETTLED. A PROTON ENHANCEMENT AT SATELLITE ALTITUDES BEGAN AT ABOUT 07/1400Z. THE ENHANCEMENT HAS NOT REACHED EVENT THRESHOLD. THE SOURCE OF THE PROTONS IS NOT CERTAIN, ALTHOUGH THE LONG DURATION C6 AT 05/2247Z IS A POSSIBILITY. THIS FLARE WAS NOT CORRELATED TO AN OPTICAL FLARE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BECOME ACTIVE FOR THE NEXT TWO DAYS DUE TO A CORONAL HOLE. THE PROTON ENHANCEMENT IS NOT EXPECTED TO REACH EVENT LEVEL.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 07/2100Z
sections.text: TO 08/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7091 (S09E43) PRODUCED AN M4/2N FLARE AT 08/1739Z. THIS FLARE WAS LONG DURATION IN X-RAYS AND WAS ACCOMPANIED WITH TYPE II/IV SWEEP ACTIVITY AND A 200 SFU RADIO BURST AT 2695 MHZ. THIS REGION APPEARS TO BE GROWING IN SUNSPOT AREA AND MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY. IN ADDITION TO THE M FLARE, IT PRODUCED C-CLASS ACTIVITY AND FREQUENT FLARE BRIGHT FLUCTUATIONS DURING THE PAST DAY. REGION 7093 (S24E53) ALSO PRODUCED M-CLASS ACTIVITY, AN M1/SF AT 08/0106Z. REGION 7081 (S15W68) IS EMERGING RAPIDLY, INCREASING ITS SUNSPOT AREA BY ABOUT SEVEN FOLD SINCE YESTERDAY. NEW REGION 7097 (S32E03) WAS NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. ISOLATED M-CLASS ACTIVITY MAY OCCUR IN REGIONS 7091 AND 7093.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 07/2100Z TO 08/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS QUIET TO UNSETTLED FOR MOST OF THE PAST 24 HOURS. ACTIVE CONDITIONS OCCURRED AT MANY STATIONS FROM 08/1200-1800Z.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE DUE TO A CORONAL HOLE. A MINOR SATELLITE PROTON EVENT AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV IS POSSIBLE AS A RESULT OF THE M4/2N FLARE MENTIONED ABOVE. THIS EVENT IS FORECAST TO BEGIN AT ABOUT 09/0600Z.

sections.text: TO 15/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 7100 (S16E11) PRODUCED AN M7/3B FLARE AT 15/0154Z. THE FLARE WAS ACCOMPANIED BY A 1400 SFU TENFLARE AND MAJOR TYPES II AND IV SWEEP BURSTS. MINOR RESTRUCTURING OCCURRED IN THE WAKE OF THE FLARE. MINOR GROWTH WAS NOTED IN REGIONS 7091 (S09W50) AND 7099 (S25E13). A SIGNIFICANT TYPE IV SWEEP BURST OCCURRED AT 15/0555Z.  NEW REGIONS 7106 (S05W75) AND 7107 (N13W10) WERE NUMBERED.

sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. REGION 7100 MAY PRODUCE ANOTHER ISOLATED MAJOR FLARE. REGIONS 7091 AND 7099 MAY PRODUCE ISOLATED M-CLASS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 14/2100Z TO 15/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. A SATELLITE LEVEL PROTON ENHANCEMENT FOLLOWED THE M7/3B FLARE. IT BEGAN NEAR 15/0600Z AND REACHED A MAXIMUM OF ABOUT 4 PFU NEAR 15/1300Z. FLUX LEVELS REMAINED ENHANCED DURING THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED DURING THE FIRST DAY. ACTIVE LEVELS ARE EXPECTED ON THE SECOND DAY DUE TO THE M7/3B FLARE. THE FIELD SHOULD SUBSIDE TO MOSTLY UNSETTLED LEVELS ON THE FINAL DAY OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.text: MODERATE.  ISOLATED CLASS M FLARES MAY OCCUR IN REGION 7099 AND 7100.  THE LARGE, OLD MAGNETIC STRUCTURE ASSOCIATED WITH REGION 7108 MAY BE SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE A RAPID RISE IN THE 10.7 CM RADIO FLUX.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. ACTIVE LEVELS WERE OBSERVED AT HIGH LATITUDES DURING THE SECOND HALF OF THE PERIOD. THE SATELLITE LEVEL PROTON FLUX AT GREATER THAN 10 MEV BARELY EXCEEDED THE 10 PFU EVENT THRESHOLD FROM 16/0840-1100Z. THE FLUX GRADUALLY DECLINED DURING THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS DURING THE FIRST DAY IN RESPONSE TO THE M7/3B FLARE OF 15 MARCH. THE FIELD IS EXPECTED TO DECLINE TO UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD.

sections.text: TO 17/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW.  CLASS C FLARES HAVE BEEN OCCURRING WITH INCREASING FREQUENCY IN SEVERAL REGIONS INCLUDING 7099 (S26W13) AND THE SPOTLESS REGION 7093 (S24W62). sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE.  FREQUENT CLASS C FLARES ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE FROM ANY OF THE DISK REGIONS.  AN OCCASIONAL M-FLARE IS POSSIBLE.  OLD REGION 7070, WHICH PRODUCED ONE CLASS X AND FOUR CLASS M FLARES ON ITS LAST DISK PASSAGE, IS DUE TO RETURN AT NO7 ON 18 MARCH AT CARRINGTON LONGITUDE 024.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 16/2100Z TO 17/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO ACTIVE LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS.  A SUDDEN IMPULSE, PROBABLY ASSOCIATED WITH THE M-7 FLARE OF 15 MARCH/0154 UT, OCCURRED AT 17/0952 UT.  THE MAGNETIC FIELD HAS TENDED TOWARD INCREASING ACTIVITY SINCE THEN BUT K-INDICES HAVE NOT EXCEEDED 5 AT THIS TIME.  NO INDICATION OF A STORM-MAIN-PHASE IS YET EVIDENT.  SATELLITE MAGNETOMETERS SHOWED A STEADILY INCREASING FIELD AT GEOSTATIONARY ORBIT FROM 17/1500 UNTIL NEARLY 2100 UT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM CONDITIONS FOR THE NEXT 15 TO 24 HOURS.  AFTER THAT, A SEVERAL-DAY PERIOD OF UNSETTLED CONDITIONS IS EXPECTED.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 27/2100Z
sections.text: TO 28/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. ONLY A FEW LOW-LEVEL C-CLASS SUBFLARES OCCURRED. THE LARGEST WAS A C2/SF FROM 7120 (S19E22) AT 1822Z. BOTH REGION 7120 AND 7117 (N07E03) SHOWED SOME GROWTH TODAY. THE DEVELOPMENT IN 7117 BRINGS THE AREA TO ABOUT 1010 MILLIONTHS. THE REGION SHOWS STRONG MAGNETIC FIELDS AND SOME AREA OF HIGH GRADIENTS, BUT REMAINS STABLE NONETHELESS.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: GENERALLY LOW. THERE IS, HOWEVER, A FAIR CHANCE FOR AN ISOLATED M-FLARE FROM REGION 7117, ESPECIALLY IF SOME KIND OF TRIGGER OR INSTABILITY EMERGES WITHIN THE REGION. REGION 7120 SHOULD CON- TINUE TO PRODUCE ADDITIONAL C-CLASS FLARES.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 28/2100Z
sections.text: TO 29/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. ONLY LOW LEVEL C-CLASS FLARES OCCURRED DURING THE PERIOD. MOST OF THESE WERE FROM REGION 7120 (S19E08) WHICH CONTINUES TO GROW AND DEVELOP. REGION 7117 (N07W11) ALSO GREW DURING THE DAY (AREA IS AT 1250 MILLIONTHS) AND PRODUCED A COUPLE OF SMALL FLARES. THE REGION SHOWS AREAS OF STRONG MAGNETIC FIELDS, BUT ITS STRUCTURE REMAINS FAIRLY SIMPLE AND IT CONTINUES TO BE STABLE.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. REGIONS 7117 AND 7120 ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE TO PRODUCE C-CLASS FLARES. THERE IS A POSSIBILTY FOR MODERATE LEVELS OF ACTIVITY, DEPENDING ON THE FUTURE DEVELOPMENT OF REGION 7117.

sections.text: TO 30/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. TODAY'S ACTIVITY CONSISTED OF A FEW SMALL C-CLASS SUBFLARES. MOST OF THESE WERE FROM NEWLY EMERGING REGION 7122 (S12W14). REGION 7117 (N07W25) CONTINUES TO BE THE LARGEST GROUP ON THE DISK AT 1270 MILLIONTHS BUT REMAINS STABLE. THE REGION'S STRONG ARCH FILAMENT SYSTEM DIS- SIPATED TODAY, INDICATING THE PROBABLE END OF GROWTH IN THE GROUP. REGION 7120 (S18W06) ALSO COOLED CONSIDERABLY AND SHOWED SOME SIGNS OF DECAY.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW. THERE CONTINUES TO BE SOME POSSIBILITY FOR AN ISOLATED M- FLARE FROM REGION 7117.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 30/2100Z
sections.text: TO 31/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7116 (S09W42) PRODUCED AN M3/1B FLARE AT 31/1545Z. THIS FLARE WAS PRECEDED BY A LONG-DURATION C6/SF IN THE SAME REGION AT 31/1436Z. NEITHER FLARE WAS ACCOMPANIED BY SIGNIFICANT RADIO BURSTS. THIS REGION HAS LOST MOST OF ITS TRAILER SPOTS. HOWEVER, THIS DECAY WAS OFFSET BY INCREASED DEVELOPMENT OF THE LEADER SPOT COMPLEX. REGION 7117 (N07W37) REMAINS THE LARGEST SUNSPOT GROUP, ALTHOUGH IT APPEARS TO BE SLOWLY DECAYING AND HAS PRODUCED ONLY SMALL C-CLASS FLARES. THE RATE OF GROWTH IN REGION 7122 (S12W29) HAS SUBSIDED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. AN ADDITIONAL M-CLASS FLARE IS POSSIBLE IN REGION 7116. REGION 7117 MAY YET PRODUCE M-CLASS ACTIVITY.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS QUIET TO UNSETTLED UNTIL ABOUT 31/1500Z. AFTERWARDS, THE FIELD WAS UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE. EFFECTS FROM A NORTHERN CORONAL HOLE MAY BE FELT BY THE END OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 31/2100Z
sections.text: TO 01/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 7116 (S08W58) PRODUCED AN M5/SF FLARE AT 01/0100Z. THE OPTICAL CLASS OF THIS EVENT WAS BASED ON A SUNSET OBSERVATION AND IS MOST CERTAINLY AN UNDERESTIMATE. THIS MAJOR FLARE WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A 240 SFU RADIO BURST AT 2695 MHZ. REGION 7116 ALSO PRODUCED AN M3/1B FLARE AT 01/1748Z AS WELL AS SEVERAL C-CLASS EVENTS. THIS REGION APPEARS TO RETAIN SOME COMPLEXITY IN SPITE OF THE FREQUENT FLARES. REGION 7117 (N07W50) IS STILL THE LARGEST SUNSPOT GROUP BUT HAS REMAINED FAIRLY INACTIVE. IT CONTINUES TO DECAY SLOWLY. NEW REGION 7123 (S07E75) WAS NUMBERED.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE. ADDITIONAL M-CLASS FLARES ARE EXPECTED IN REGION 7116. REGION 7117 MAY PRODUCE M-CLASS ACTIVITY BEFORE IT REACHES THE WEST LIMB.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE UNTIL ABOUT 01/1500Z, AND AFTERWARDS IT WAS MOSTLY QUIET.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE QUIET TO UNSETTLED AT MIDDLE LATITUDES AND ACTIVE TO STORM AT HIGH LATITUDES.

sections.text: TO 03/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. ONLY SMALL FLARES FROM A NUMBER OF DIFFERENT REGIONS HAVE BEEN OBSERVED SINCE YESTERDAY. REGIONS 7116 (S08W85) AND 7117 (N07W77) ARE QUIETLY APPROACHING THE WEST LIMB. REGION 7123 (S06E55) IS NOW FULLY IN VIEW. THIS REGION HAS A SIMPLE BIPOLAR CONFIGURATION AND IS OF MODERATE SIZE. REGION 7124 (N14W36) IS EMERGING RAPIDLY. SUNSPOT AREA HAS INCREASED FROM 10 MILLIONTHS TO WELL OVER 100 MILLIONTHS WITHIN THE PAST DAY.

sections.text: LOW. C-CLASS FLARES ARE EXPECTED IN REGIONS 7123 AND 7124. THESE REGIONS MAY ALSO PRODUCE ISOLATED M-CLASS ACTIVITY.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 02/2100Z TO 03/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS MOSTLY QUIET UNTIL SHORTLY AFTER 03/0600Z. THE FIELD WAS AT ACTIVE TO STORM LEVELS THEREAFTER. THE GRADUAL ONSET OF THE DISTURBANCE SUGGESTS THAT THE LARGE CORONAL HOLE IN THE NORTHERN SOLAR HEMISPHERE IS THE SOURCE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT ACTIVE TO STORM LEVELS FOR THE NEXT DAY OR SO. THE FIELD SHOULD RETURN TO MOSTLY UNSETTLED CONDITIONS BY THE THIRD DAY.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 03/2100Z
sections.text: TO 04/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. FREQUENT SMALL FLARES WERE OBSERVED SINCE YESTERDAY FROM REGIONS 7123 (S06E41) AND 7124 (N14W47). REGION 7123 IS THE LARGEST AND MOST ACTIVE OF THE TWO. SUNSPOT DEVELOPMENT IS APPARENT IN THE TRAILER PORTION OF THIS GROUP AND THE MAGNETIC STRUCTURE HAS BECOME SLIGHTLY MORE COMPLEX SINCE YESTERDAY. GROWTH IN REGION 7124 APPEARS TO BE PEAKING. PLAGE IS LESS EXTENSIVE AND LESS BRIGHT THAN YESTERDAY. MAGNETICALLY, THIS REGION APPEARS TO BE A SIMPLE, BIPOLAR GROUP. A NINE DEGREE SEGMENT OF FILAMENT NEAR N23W70 DISAPPEARED FROM 04/1905-1930Z. THIS FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCE WAS SHORTLY FOLLOWED BY THE SLOW ERUPTION OF AN ACTIVE PROMINANCE NEAR NW37. THESE EVENTS WERE ASSOCIATED WITH A SLOW RISE IN X-RAYS PEAKING AT C2 AT 04/1927Z.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW. C-CLASS FLARES ARE EXPECTED IN REGION 7123 AND ARE POSSIBLE IN REGION 7124. AN ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARE IS POSSIBLE IN 7123. THERE IS AN OUTSIDE CHANCE OF AN M-FLARE IN 7124.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 16/2100Z
sections.text: TO 17/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. C-CLASS ACTIVITY WAS MORE FREQUENT OVER THE PAST 24 HOURS WITH REGION 7135 (S15E66) HAVING THE MOST FLARES. ITS LARGEST EFFORT WAS A C4/0F AT 1829Z. REGION 7132 (S26E27) HAD A FEW FLARES AS IT CONTINUED TO GROW IN WHITE LIGHT AND H-ALPHA. ONE NEW REGION, 7136 (N19E60) WAS NUMBERED. SIGNIFICANT SURGE AND ACTIVE PROMINENCE ACTIVITY OCCURRED BOTH NORTH AND SOUTH AT EAST LIMB, POSSIBLY HERALDING THE RETURN OF A BAND OF PREVIOUSLY ACTIVE LONGITUDES. THESE SOON-TO-ARRIVE ACTIVE REGIONS MAY BE RESPONSIBLE FOR TODAY'S LARGE INCREASE IN THE 10.7 CM RADIO FLUX.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW. M-CLASS FLARES ARE INCREASINGLY MORE LIKELY OVER TIME, PENDING FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF REGIONS 7132 AND 7135 AND THE IMMINENT RETURN OF OLD ACTIVE REGIONS 7116 AND 7117.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT MOSTLY QUIET LEVELS.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE QUIET TO UNSETTLED UNTIL 20 APRIL. A NARROW EQUATORWARD EXTENSION OF THE SOUTHERN POLAR CROWN CORONAL HOLE WILL BE FAVORABLY LOCATED LATE IN THE INTERVAL AND LIKELY SPAWN A BRIEF EPISODE OF DISTURBED CONDITIONS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 17/2100Z
sections.text: TO 18/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. THE FIRST M-CLASS FLARE SINCE 01 APRIL, AN M1/0F AT 17/2327Z, ORIGINATED IN REGION 7135 (S16E54). THE REGION CONTINUED TO GENERATE SMALLER FLARES TODAY, ALTHOUGH ITS PACE HAS SLOWED LATELY. STRONG ARCH- FILAMENTS AND CONTINUED SLOW GROWTH HAVE BEEN REPORTED, WITH THE HOTTEST PLAGE NEAR THE TRAILER SPOTS. MORE EAST LIMB ACTIVITY AND THE POSSIBLE ARRIVAL OF MORE ACTIVE CENTERS MARK THE ARRIVAL OF AN ACTIVE BAND OF LONGITUDES THAT INCLUDE REGION 7135 AND NEWLY ASSIGNED REGION 7137 (S18E69). A SMALL FILAMENT DISAPPEARED FROM THIS SAME AREA (N10E70) AROUND 1700Z. THE 10.7 CM RADIO FLUX TOOK ANOTHER LARGE JUMP, SURPASSING THE 200 LEVEL FOR THE FIRST TIME SINCE 01 MARCH.

sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. REGION 7135 IS THE PRIME CANDIDATE FOR AN ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARE. REGIONS 7137, 7132 (S27E16) AND 7128 (S14W48) MAY YIELD SMALLER FLARES.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE THE NEXT 48 HOURS. CORONAL HOLE EFFECTS ARE DUE DURING THAT TIME. STRICTLY UNSETTLED CONDITIONS SHOULD END THE INTERVAL.

THE GROUP WAS NOT REMARKABLE IN ANY OTHER RESPECT AND SHOWED PHOTOSPHERIC AND CHROMOSPHERIC SIMPLICITY AND STABILITY. REGION 7135 (S16W00) CONTINUES TO BE THE LARGEST GROUP ON THE DISK AND SHOWED SOME RESTRUCTURING, INCLUDING THE FORMATION OF A SMALL DELTA NEAR THE REGION'S CENTER. NONETHELESS THE GROUP COULD ONLY MUSTER A COUPLE OF SUBFLARES DURING THE DAY. REGIONS 7137 (S19E18) AND 7138 (N10E23) ALSO SHOWED MINOR GROWTH AND PRODUCED A COUPLE OF SUBFLARES. REGION 7138 APPEARS TO ALSO HAVE A DELTA CONFIGURATION. NOTE ALSO THAT TODAY'S 10.7 CM FLUX DROPPED DESPITE GROWTH AND EMERGENCE OF NEW REGIONS ON THE DISK.

sections.text: TO 23/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 7135 (S17W13) PRO- DUCED TODAY'S LARGEST FLARE: A C3/1N AT 0237Z. THE GROUP SHOWED GROWTH EARLY IN THE DAY BUT WAS INDICATING DECLINE FOR THE LATTER PART OF THE PERIOD. IT CONTINUES TO EXHIBIT A SMALL DELTA NEAR REGION CENTER, AND IT PRODUCED A FEW ADDITIONAL SUBFLARES. REGION 7138 (N10E09) SHOWED SOME GROWTH AND MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY AS IT PRODUCED A FEW C-CLASS SUBFLARES DURING THE PERIOD. sections.text: TO 24/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7138 (N10W03) PRODUCED TWO M-CLASS FLARES TODAY: AN M1/1B AT 1253Z AND AN M1/1B AT 1920Z. THE GROUP SHOWS A DELTA CONFIGURATION WHICH APPEARS TO BE SHEARING AND THUS PROVIDING THE IMPETUS FOR THE M-FLARES AS WELL AS ADDITIONAL FREQUENT SMALL FLARES. THERE IS SOME INDICATION THAT THE REGION IS BEGINNING TO DECAY. REGION 7135 (S17W26) HAS BEEN QUIET AND IS SLOWLY DECAYING: THE MAGNETIC FIELDS WERE MORE RELAXED TODAY AND THE DELTA CONFIGURATION IS GONE. REGION 7143 (S06E55) HAS SHOWN MODEST GROWTH AND HAS A WEAK SIMPLE DELTA: THE GROUP PRODUCED OCCASIONAL C-CLASS FLARES. THREE LARGE FILAMENTS DISAPPEARED FROM THE SOLAR DISK: A 22 DEGREE FILAMENT AT N30W20, A 25 DEGREE FILAMENT AT N33W36, AND A 23 DEGREE FILAMENT AT S41E13.

sections.text: TO 05/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE.  REGION 7154 (S26E39) HAS PRODUCED ANOTHER CLASS M1 FLARE.  THE X-RAY EVENT WAS MARKED BY A SLOW, IRREGULAR RISE, INDICATING SMALL BUT COMPLEX STRUCTURES WERE INVOLVED IN THE EVENT.  THE REGION HAS A SMALL, COMPACT, AND GROWING SUNSPOT STRUCTURE.  THE MAGNETIC STRUCTURE HAS BEEN SIMPLE.  THE REGION WOULD APPEAR TO BE A YOUNG, GROWING REGION EARLY IN ITS DEVELOPMENT.  HOWEVER, IT IS SURROUNDED AND CONNECTED TO A NETWORK OF FILAMENTS TYPICAL OF A MORE MATURE REGION.  IT HAS PRODUCED FREQUENT, SMALL CLASS C FLARES.  REGION 7150 (S06W61) HAS PRODUCED CLASS C SUBFLARES AS WELL.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE TO HIGH. sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 05/2100Z
sections.text: TO 06/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW.  THE MOST INTENSE FLARE OVER THE PAST 24 HOURS WAS A CLASS C3 EVENT AT 06/1000UT WITH NO OPTICAL COUNTERPART REPORTED.  MINOR FLARES UP TO CLASS C2 HAVE OCCURRED IN REGIONS 7150 (S06 WEST LIMB) AND 7154 (S25 E28).  THE LATTER REGION HAS GROWN SLOWLY IN SUNSPOT AREA. MT WILSON MAGNETIC DATA SHOWS IT TO BE BETA-GAMMA.  THE FILAMENTS EXTENDING INTO THE REGION APPEAR LESS DISTINCT THAN 24 TO 48 HOURS AGO WHILE A LARGE FILAMENT EXTENDING TOWARD THE EAST LIMB FROM NEAR THE REGION APPEARS AS IF IT MAY BE READY TO LIFT FROM THE DISK.  ACROSS THE SURFACE OF THE SUN, SMALL, SIMPLE SUNSPOT GROUPS CONTINUE TO APPEAR FOR A FEW HOURS, THEN FADE FROM SIGHT.  THE IMPLICATION OF THIS PHENOMENON IS UNKNOWN TO ORDINARY FORECASTERS AND OBSERVERS.  THE 10.7 CM RADIO FLUX HAS HOVERED IN THE RANGE 130 TO 140 FOR THE PAST 9 DAYS.  VETERAN SOLAR CYCLE OBSERVERS HAVE SUGGESTED THAT THIS LULL, MOVING TO LOWER FLUX VALUES AT THESE SOLAR LONGITUDES FOR SEVERAL ROTATIONS, MARK THE BEGINNING OF THE FIRST, STEEP DECLINE FROM THE PLATEAU OF HIGH VALUES THAT HAVE HELD SINCE THE BEGINNING OF 1989. THE NORTHERN HEMISPHERE OF THE CURRENT FACE OF THE SUN IS MARKED BY A VERY LARGE AREA DEVOID OF SIGNIFICANT STRUCTURES OF ANY KIND.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE.  REGION 7154 MAY CONTINUE TO DEVELOP, THOUGH AT A SLOWER RATE.  IT REMAINS THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE OF ENERGETIC ACTIVITY.  IF THE PRESENT DECLINE OF 10.7 CM FLUX CONTINUES, IT WILL BE THE FIRST OF SEVERAL THAT WILL MARK THE DECLINE OF THE PRESENT CYCLE TO MINIMUM OVER THE NEXT 4 OR 5 YEARS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 05/2100Z TO 06/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS.  THOUGH NOT A DISTURBANCE AT THIS POINT, GROUND-BASED AND GEOSYNCHRONOUS SATELLITE MAGNETOMETERS BEGAN SHOWING A DIFFERENT TYPE OF PATTERN, SHIFTING FROM SMOOTH TO A SMALL BUT DISTINCT LEVEL OF DISTURBANCE THAT MAY MARK THE FIRST EFFECTS OF THE VERY-LONG-DURATION X-RAY EVENT THAT OCCURRED ON MAY 4.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE QUIET BUT WITH A CHANCE OF UNSETTLED-TO- ACTIVE CONDITIONS FOR THE NEXT TWO OR THREE DAYS FOLLOWED BY A RETURN TO QUIET LEVELS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 06/2100Z
sections.text: TO 07/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. A C3/2F HYDER FLARE AT 0649Z FROM S23E48 WAS THE LARGEST EVENT OF THE PERIOD. THIS FLARE WAS THE PRECURSOR TO A LARGE EPL AT S21E90 WITH MATERIAL VISIBLE TO .58 SOLAR RADII. THE FILAMENT WHICH LIFTED OFF WAS THE SAME ONE ELUDED TO IN YESTERDAY'S FORECAST. STRONG TYPE II AND IV RADIO SWEEPS WERE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS EVENT AND SHOCK SPEEDS WERE ESTIMATED AS HIGH AS 2000 KM/SEC. ELSEWHERE, REGION 7154 (S25, E14) CONTINUES TO BE THE LARGEST AND MOST COMPLEX GROUP ON THE DISK BUT MAY HAVE STARTED TO DECAY AND ELONGATE. ONE NEW REGION WAS NUMBERED, REGION 7161 AT (S08, E21).

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MOSTLY LOW. AN ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARE IS STILL POSSIBLE FROM REGION 7154.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY QUIET TO UNSETTLED. THE POSSIBILITY OF A SHOCK FROM TODAY'S EPL WITH TYPE II AND IV SWEEPS APPEARS SLIGHT AT THIS TIME. HOWEVER, IF A SHOCK WAS TO OCCUR, THE BEST ESTIMATES OF TIME OF ARRIVAL ARE LATE ON DAY TWO TO EARLY ON DAY THREE.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 07/2100Z
sections.text: TO 08/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS HIGH. REGION 7154 (S26E08) PRODUCED AN IMPRESSIVE M7/4B FLARE WITH PARALLEL RIBBONS AND NUMEROUS ERUPTIVE CENTERS.  FLARE AREA WAS REPORTED TO BE 1299 MILLIONTHS.  ASSOCIATED WITH THE FLARE WERE A TYPE IV RADIO SWEEP AND A TENFLARE (2695 MHZ BURST) OF 3100 SFU. A FILAMENT AT ONE END OF THE REGION BECAME ACTIVE DURING THE FLARE AND DISAPPEARED.  TWO NEW REGIONS WERE NUMBERED TODAY: 7162 (N07W11) AND 7163 (S18E67).

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE.  REGION 7154 IS THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE OF ADDITIONAL M-CLASS FLARES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 07/2100Z TO 08/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT UNSETTLED TO MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS THE NEXT THREE DAYS, WITH PREDOMINANTLY MINOR STORM CONDITIONS ON DAY TWO. ACTIVITY SHOULD INCREASE FAIRLY EARLY ON THE 9TH DUE TO THE EPL/HYDER FLARE/TYPE II AND IV ON THE 7TH.  THE M7 FLARE TODAY IS EXPECTED TO PRODUCE MINOR STORM CONDITIONS IN THE LATTER HALF OF THE 10TH AND INTO THE 11TH. A PROTON EVENT IS EXPECTED TO START BY 09/00Z FOR >10 MEV PROTONS.  EVENT CRITERIA IS NOT EXPECTED TO BE REACHED FOR HIGHER ENERGY PROTONS.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 08/2100Z
sections.text: TO 09/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY HAS BEEN VERY LOW SINCE YESTERDAY'S M7. THE BEST REGION 7154 (S25, W12) COULD MUSTER WAS A B6/SF FROM A B3 X-RAY BACKGROUND. THERE WERE SEVERAL DISAPPEARING FILAMENTS NOTED TODAY, THE LARGEST WAS 35 DEGREES CENTERED AT S42E82.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. REGION 7154 HAS SHOWN SOME DECAY SINCE THE M7 BUT MAY STILL BE CAPABLE OF ANOTHER ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENT. REGION 7162 (N07W25) HAS DISPLAYED SOME MODERATE GROWTH OVER THE PERIOD AND MAY ALSO BE CAPABLE OF ISOLATED M-CLASS FLARING.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 08/2100Z TO 09/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT UNSETTLED TO MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. MOSTLY UNSETTLED CONDITIONS PREVAILED UNTIL A SUDDEN IMPULSE OF 55 NANOTESLA WAS MEASURED AT BOULDER AT 1601Z. AT 1955Z A SUDDEN STORM COMMENCEMENT OF 31 NANOTESLA WAS RECORDED AT BOULDER. A PROTON EVENT AT THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV LEVEL BEGAN AT 1005Z IN RESPONSE TO YESTERDAY'S M7. A SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN THE PROTON FLUX WAS NOTED IN CONCERT WITH THE SSC. CURRENT MAXIMUM FOR THE EVENT IS 4200 PFU AT 2035Z. HIGHER ENERGY PROTONS HAVE REMAINED BELOW EVENT THRESHOLDS THUS FAR. A POLAR CAP ABSORPTION EVENT BEGAN AT 1405Z WITH A CURRENT MAXIMUM OF 18 DECIBELS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MOSTLY MINOR STORM LEVELS THROUGH DAY TWO. ANOTHER SHOCK IS ANTICIPATED AROUND 1500Z ON 10 APRIL IN RESPONSE TO THE M7 FROM REGION 7154 ON 08 APRIL. THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTONS SHOULD BE NEAR THEIR PEAK FLUX. A SLOW DECLINE IN EXPECTED TO BEGIN SHORTLY. A SLIGHT INCREASE IS POSSIBLE AGAIN WITH THE ANTICIPATED SHOCK ON 10 APRIL. BY 12 APRIL CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY UNSETTLED AGAIN.

sections.text: TO 10/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS VERY LOW. REGION 7162 (N08W39) PRODUCED TWO ISOLATED SUBFLARES. REGION 7154 (S25W25) DECLINED SLIGHTLY IN SIZE AND SPOT COUNT. AN ERUPTIVE PROMINENCE REACHING 0.08 SOLAR RADII OCCURRED AT 10/0910Z NEAR N23E89. A 25 DEGREE FILAMENT LOCATED NEAR S08E50 DISAPPEARED SOMETIME AFTER 09/1700Z. NO NEW REGIONS WERE ASSIGNED.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 09/2100Z TO 10/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT MINOR TO SEVERE STORM LEVELS. THE SEVERE STORMING OCCURRED FROM 10/0900-1800Z. THIS DISTURBANCE WAS PROBABLY IN RESPONSE TO THE LONG DURATION C3/2F FLARE OF 07/0715Z. THE M7/4B FLARE OF 08/1546Z PROBABLY CONTRIBUTED TO THE DISTURBANCE AS WELL. THE M7/4B FLARE ALSO CAUSED THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV PROTON EVENT THAT BEGAN AT 09/1005Z AND REACHED A MAXIMUM OF 4600 PFU AT 09/2100Z. THE GREATER THAN 10 MEV FLUX WAS AT ABOUT 20 PFU AND GRADUALLY DECREASING AT THE END OF THE PERIOD. THE POLAR CAP ABSORPTION EVENT WHICH BEGAN AT 09/1405Z REACHED AN ESTIMATED MAXIMUM OF 20.4 DB AT 09/2100Z AND GRADUALLY DECLINED THEREAFTER.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE AT MINOR TO MAJOR STORM LEVELS DURING THE FIRST HALF OF DAY ONE, GRADUALLY DECLINING TO MOSTLY ACTIVE LEVELS THROUGH THE SECOND DAY. THE FINAL DAY IS EXPECTED TO AT MOSTLY UNSETTLED LEVELS. THE PROTON AND POLAR CAP ABSORPTION EVENTS ARE EXPECTED TO END DURING THE FIRST DAY OF THE FORECAST PERIOD.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 18/2100Z
sections.text: TO 19/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 7172 (N22E41) GREW RAPIDLY TODAY TO A 230 MILLIONTHS DAO GROUP. THE REGION PRODUCED FREQUENT LOW LEVEL C-CLASS FLARES AND SHOWED BRIGHT PLAGE DURING THE PERIOD. THE OTHER SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS WERE SIMPLE, STABLE AND QUIET. A 23 DEGREE FILAMENT DISAPPEARED FROM THE NORTHEAST QUADRANT SOMETIME BETWEEN 18/2302Z AND 19/0550Z.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MOSTLY LOW, WITH A CHANCE FOR AN ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENT. REGION 7172 IS EXPECTED TO BE THE PREDOMINANT SOURCE OF SOLAR ACTIVITY FOR THE NEXT THREE DAYS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 18/2100Z TO 19/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO ACTIVE LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. ACTIVE CONDITIONS PREVAILED FROM THE BEGINNING OF THE PERIOD THROUGH ABOUT 0600Z, PRESUMABLY DUE TO A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE. ACTIVITY LEVELS DECLINED TO MOSTLY QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE REMAIN- DER OF THE PERIOD, WITH SOME ISOLATED ACTIVE PERIODS AT HIGH LATITUDES.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE GENERALLY UNSETTLED. SOME PERIODS OF ACTIVE LEVELS ARE ANTICIPATED LATE ON THE 21ST THROUGH EARLY ON THE 22ND DUE TO POSSIBLE EFFECTS FROM ANOTHER CORONAL HOLE AND FROM TODAY'S DISAPPEARING FILAMENT.

sections.text: TO 22/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. SMALL FLARES FROM A VARIETY OF SMALL REGIONS WAS THE GENERAL RULE FOR THE PAST DAY. THE LARGEST X-RAY FLARE WAS A C1/1N IN REGION 7177 (S23W32). sections.text: LOW. SMALL FLARES ARE EXPECTED FROM A NUMBER OF REGIONS. THERE IS A SMALL CHANCE OF M-CLASS ACTIVITY IN REGION 7172.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO RETURN TO QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS AT MIDDLE LATITUDES BY TOMORROW. THE DISTURBANCE MAY PERSIST AT HIGH LATITUDES FOR THE NEXT DAY OR SO.

sections.text: TO 31/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. AN UNASSOCIATED C1 X-RAY EVENT OCCURRED 30/2229Z. REGION 7185 (N12E13) HAS GROWN RAPIDLY FROM AN A-TYPE TO A C-TYPE GROUP, AND HAS PRODUCED SEVERAL SUB- FLARES WITH SMALL X-RAY ENHANCEMENTS. A STRONG ARCH FILAMENT SYSTEM IS IN PROGRESS THERE. SPOTLESS REGION 7178 (S23W46) PRODUCED A SUBFAINT PARALLEL RIBBON FLARE AT 31/1228Z. NO NEW REGIONS WERE IDENTIFIED. TWO FILAMENTS DISAPPEARED BETWEEN 30/2115Z AND 31/1438Z (OVERNIGHT). THE FIRST WAS 15 DEGREES LONG AND WAS LOCATED NEAR N10E60 ON 30 MAY; THE SECOND WAS ABOUT 10 DEGREES LONG AND WAS LOCATED NEAR S35W40. THE SOLAR LIMBS WERE QUIET EXCEPT FOR AN ACTIVE PROMINENCE NEAR S15W90.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 31/2100Z
sections.text: TO 01/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 7183 (S26E46) PRODUCED A C1/1F FLARE 31 MAY/2359Z. NO OTHER C-CLASS OR LARGER X-RAY EVENTS, OR OPTICAL FLARES HAVE BEEN OBSERVED. NEW REGION 7186 (N08E79) ROTATED OVER THE EAST LIMB WITH SOME ASSOCIATED SURGING; IT IS PRESENTLY SEEN AS AN H-TYPE SPOT. REGION 7185 (N12E01) APPEARS TO HAVE STABLIZED AS A D-TYPE GROUP WITHOUT MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY. A SIGNIFICANT FILAMENT (APPROXIMATELY 20 DEGREES LONG) DISAPPEARED FROM NEAR CENTER DISK TODAY. THE CENTER OF THE FILAMENT ON 31 MAY WAS NEAR S15E05. ACTIVE PROMINENCES WERE REPORTED NEAR N16W90 AND S20E90.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW.  ONLY OCCASIONAL ERUPTIVE FLARES ARE EXPECTED FROM REGIONS PRESENTLY ON THE SOLAR DISK.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BECOME ACTIVE TOMORROW, REMAINING UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE ON 03 JUNE IN RESPONSE TO EFFECTS ASSOCIATED WITH FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCES. QUIET CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED BY THE END OF THE FORECAST PERIOD, BUT THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD MAY BECOME DISTURBED THEREAFTER, AGAIN IN RESPONSE TO FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCES.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 01/2100Z
sections.text: TO 02/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS VERY LOW. REGION 7186 (S08E72) IS THE MOST SIGNIFICANT REGION IN WHITE LIGHT AND H-ALPHA, BUT IS NOT MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX AND HAS PRODUCED ONLY 1 SUBFLARE TODAY. A SURGING AREA OF COMPACT PLAGE IS ROTATING ONTO THE DISK BEHIND IT. NEW REGION 7187 (S08E71), AN A-TYPE SPOT, CAME ONTO THE DISK NEAR THE VICINITY OF OLD REGION 7160. SEVERAL MINOR FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCES WERE NOTED. SURGING WAS REPORTED AT S10W90 NEAR DEPARTED SPOTLESS REGION 7179. THERE WAS AN ACTIVE PROMINENCE NEAR S17E90.

sections.text: TO 03/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS VERY LOW. HOWEVER, THERE ARE NOW 7 SPOTTED REGIONS ON THE VISIBLE DISK INCLUDING NEW REGIONS 7188 (N08W01) AND 7189 (N05E30). SIGNIFICANT GROWTH OCCURRED IN REGION 7181 (N08W27). SPOTS BEHIND REGION 7186 (N09E55) MAY OR MAY NOT BE ASSOCIATED WTIH IT; IDENTIFICATION IS DIFFICULT DUE TO LIMB PROXIMITY. sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE QUIET TOMORROW, BECOMING MOSTLY ACTIVE ON THE NEXT DAY DUE TO POSSIBLE EFFECTS FROM A FILAMENT DISAPPEARANCE BETWEEN 31 MAY AND 01 JUNE. sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 06/2100Z
sections.text: TO 07/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7186 (N08W01) PRODUCED THE FIRST M-CLASS FLARE SINCE MAY 8, AN M2/2B AT 0148Z. ASSOCIATED WITH THE EVENT WERE MODEST RADIO BURSTS ACROSS THE SPECTRUM (210 SFU AT 2695 MHZ) AND A TYPE II SWEEP. THE PREFERRED FLARE SITE WITHIN THE PLAGE SHIFTED IN THE PAST 24 HOURS, FROM NORTH CENTRAL TO NEAR THE ACTIVE EMBEDDED FILAMENT NEAR THE SOUTH CENTRAL SPOTS. STRUCTURALLY, THE REGION REMAINS A BETA-GAMMA AND HAS NOT CHANGED SUBSTANTIALLY IN OBSERVABLES. ELSEWHERE, REGION 7192 (N09E33) HAS GROWN IN WHITE LIGHT WHILE GENERATING AN OCCASIONAL SUBFLARE, AND REGION 7191 (N08E10), JUST AFT OF REGION 7186, HAS SHOWN SIGNS OF LIFE.

sections.text: LOW. HOWEVER, REGION 7186 MAY MUSTER ANOTHER M-CLASS FLARE AT SOME POINT IN THE NEXT THREE DAYS.

sections.text: TO 08/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE. REGION 7186 (N09W14) GENERATED ITS SECOND M-CLASS FLARE IN TWO DAYS. THE M1/1B PARALLEL RIBBON FLARE - MAX AT 0849Z - WAS ACCOMPANIED BY BOTH TYPES II AND IV SWEEP. THE DURATION OF THE TYPE IV WAS OVER 3 HOURS. THE REGION IS LARGELY UNCHANGED OVER THE PAST 24 HOURS, AND STILL HAS AN ACTIVE INVERSION LINE FILAMENT. REGION 7192 (N09E33) PRODUCED A FEW SUBFLARES, MOST ORIGINATING NE OF THE LEADER SPOTS. sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS THE PAST 24 HOURS. THIS DISTURBANCE, LACKING A WELL-DEFINED SOLAR SOURCE, IS LIKELY DUE MORE TO THE SOUTHWARD TURNING OF THE IMF RATHER THAN A DISTINCT CME.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE PREDOMINANTLY UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE THE NEXT THREE DAYS. SOME RESPONSE TO TODAY'S M1/1B WITH LENGTHY TYPE IV MAY OCCUR NEAR THE LATTER PART OF THE INTERVAL.

sections.title: ANALYSIS OF SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS AND ACTIVITY FROM 08/2100Z
sections.text: TO 09/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 7186 (N09W26) PRO- DUCED TODAY'S LARGEST FLARE: A C5/1F AT 0232Z. THE GROUP ALSO PRODUCED A C4/1N AT 0630Z WHICH WAS ACCOMPANIED BY TYPE II AND TYPE IV RADIO SWEEPS. THE LATTER FLARE APPEARS TO HAVE GREATLY STABILIZED THE REGION: THE GROUP WAS QUIET AND SHOWED SLOW DECAY FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD. SIGNIFICANT NEW GROWTH WAS NOTED TODAY IN REGION 7191 (N10W16). THIS GROUP SHOWED FREQUENT BRIGHT PLAGE FLUCTUATIONS AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF SOME MAGNETIC COMPLEXITY. REGION 7192 (N09E06) WAS QUIET AND STABLE. NEW REGION 7194 (S11E74) ROTATED INTO VIEW TODAY AND PRODUCED A FEW SUBFLARES.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: LOW TO MODERATE. REGION 7191 AND 7186 ARE CONSIDERED TO BE THE MOST LIKELY SOURCES FOR AN ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENT SOMETIME OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 08/2100Z TO 09/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE PERIOD BEGAN AT ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS AS YESTERDAY'S DISTRUBANCE PERSISTED THROUGH ABOUT 09/1200Z. AFTER 1200Z AND THROUGH THE REMAINDER OF THE PERIOD THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS MOSTLY QUIET TO UNSET- TLED.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY QUIET TO UNSETTLED WITH OCCASIONAL ACTIVE PERIODS DUE TO SUBSTORM EFFECTS OVER THE NEXT 24 HOURS. BY DAY TWO AN INCREASE TO GENERALLY ACTIVE LEVELS IS ANTICIPATED AS A RESPONSE TO THE M1/TYPE IV FLARE OF 08 JUNE. CONDITIONS SHOULD GRADUALLY SUBSIDE DURING THE THIRD DAY.

sections.text: LOW. REGION 7191 COULD DEVELOP SHEAR BUT POSSESSES WEAK MAGNETIC FIELDS AND IS LIKELY ONLY TO PRODUCE SMALL FLARES. REGION 7194 HAS ONE FAIRLY LARGE LEADER SPOT BUT THE LEADER IS FOLLOWED BY RATHER WIDELY DISPERSED FIELDS OF OPPOSITE POLARITY AND IS EX- PECTED TO PRODUCE ONLY SMALL FLARES.

sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD RANGED FROM QUIET TO MINOR STORM LEVELS. QUIET TO UNSETTLED CONDITIONS BEGAN THE PERIOD AND WERE FOL- LOWED BY ABOUT 12 HOURS OF ACTIVE CONDITIONS FROM 10/0300Z TO 10/1500Z; SOME BRIEF MINOR STORM PERIODS WERE REPORTED DURING THIS TIME AS WELL. ACTIVITY WAS QUIET TO UNSETTLED FROM 1500Z THROUGH THE END OF THE PERIOD.

sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE ACTIVE TOMORROW AND PARTWAY THROUGH THE SECOND DAY IN RESPONSE TO THE M1 FLARE OF 08 JUNE. CONDITIONS SHOULD DECLINE TO GENERALLY UNSETTLED LEVELS BY THE THIRD DAY.

sections.text: TO 11/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW. REGION 7191 (N14W43) PRO- DUCED TWO C1 FLARES TODAY. THE GROUP HAS SHOWN CONTINUED GROWTH AND HAS MERGED WITH REGION 7193; THE TWO REGIONS HAVE BEEN COMBINED INTO A SINGLE REGION 7191. sections.text: BE LOW. REGION 7191 IS EXPECTED TO BE THE MAIN SOURCE FOR OC- CASIONAL C-CLASS FLARES OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS. THERE IS A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR AN ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 10/2100Z TO 11/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS MOSTLY UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. IN PARTICULAR A TRANSITION TO DISTURBED LEVELS BEGAN AROUND 18Z WHICH RESULTED IN STRONGLY ACTIVE LEVELS AT MID-LATITUDES AND MINOR STORM LEVELS CONDITIONS AT SOME HIGH LATITUDE SITES. THIS INCREASE IS MOST LIKELY DUE TO EFFECTS FROM THE M1 FLARE OF 08 JUNE, ALTHOUGH A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE MAY ALSO BE A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE GENERALLY ACTIVE WITH PERIODS OF MINOR STORM CONDITIONS FOR THE NEXT 12 HOURS AS THE CURRENT DISTURBANCE PERSISTS. CONDITIONS SHOULD RETURN TO MOSTLY UNSETTLED THERE- AFTER, WITH POSSIBLE ISOLATED ACTIVE PERIODS AT HIGH LATITUDES.

sections.text: TO 12/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS VERY LOW. REGION 7191 (N12W58) APPEARS TO HAVE STABILIZED FROM ITS INITIAL GROWTH PHASE AND DID NOT PRODUCE ANY FLARES. sections.text: LOW. REGION 7191, 7192 AND 7194 APPEAR TO BE THE MOST LIKELY SOURCES FOR C-LEVEL FLARE ACTIVITY. THERE IS A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR AN ISOLATED M-CLASS EVENT OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 11/2100Z TO 12/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS AT MOSTLY ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM LEVELS DURING THE PERIOD. ACTIVITY WAS PARTICULARLY ENHANCED FROM 1200-1800Z AS MID-LATITUDES EXPERIENCED MINOR STORM LEVEL ACTIVITY AND HIGH LATITUDES REPORTED MAJOR TO SEVERE STORM CONDITIONS. ACTIVITY APPEARED TO BE DIMINISHING NEAR THE END OF THE DAY. THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE FOR THIS DIS- TURBANCE WAS THE C4/TYPE II FLARE/SWEEP OF 09 JUNE.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE MOSTLY ACTIVE FOR THE NEXT 12 HOURS AS THE CUR- RENT DISTURBANCE PERSISTS. CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO DECLINE TO GENERALLY UNSETTLED LEVELS WITH OCCASIONAL ACTIVE PERIODS THEREAFTER AND THROUGH THE END OF THE 2ND DAY. AN INCREASE TO MOSTLY ACTIVE LEVELS IS POSSIBLE BY THE THIRD DAY IN RESPONSE TO TODAY'S DISAPPEARING FILAMENTS.

sections.text: LOW. REGION 7191 IS EXPECTED TO PRODUCE OCCASIONAL C-CLASS FLARES OVER THE NEXT THREE DAYS AS IT TRANSITS THE WEST LIMB. sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE GENERALLY UNSETTLED TOMORROW, UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE ON THE SECOND DAY, AND GENERALLY UNSETTLED ON THE THIRD DAY. THE INCREASE ON THE SECOND DAY IS ANTICIPATED AS A RE- SPONSE TO DISAPPEARING FILAMENTS OF 12 JUNE AND A FAVORABLY POSITIONED CORONAL HOLE.

sections.text: TO 26/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS MODERATE, DUE TO AN ISOLATED M FLARE FROM REGION 7205 (N10W87) AT 0415UT.  SOLAR OBSERVERS ARE REPORTING SOME INDICATIONS THAT THIS REGION IS BEGINNING TO FRAGMENT AS IT APPROACHES WEST LIMB.  IT REMAINS LARGE (OVER 1000 MILLIONTHS) AND MAGNETICALLY COMPLEX (BETA-GAMMA- DELTA).  REMAINING REGIONS ARE SMALL AND RELATIVELY QUIET. THE LARGE NORTH-SOUTH FILAMENT LOCATED NEAR N10W25 YESTERDAY IS NO LONGER VISIBLE.  A LARGE CORONAL HOLE IS SITUATED BETWEEN THIS FILAMENT LOCATION AND REGION 7205.

sections.title: SOLAR ACTIVITY FORECAST:  SOLAR ACTIVITY IS EXPECTED TO BE
sections.text: MODERATE.  M FLARES ARE EXPECTED FROM REGION 7205.  ANOTHER MAJOR FLARE IS POSSIBLE FROM THIS REGION DURING ITS WEST LIMB TRANSIT.  OLD REGION 7186 (N11 L119), WHICH PRODUCED TWO M FLARES LAST ROTATION, IS DUE BACK ON 28 JUN.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 25/2100Z TO 26/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD HAS BEEN AT QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS FOR THE PAST 24 HOURS. THE PROTON AND PCA EVENTS WHICH BEGAN YESTERDAY ARE STILL IN PROGRESS.  THE PEAK P10 FLUX WAS 390PFU AT 0610UT.  THE MAXIMUM RIOMETER ABSORPTION AT THULE WAS 5.6DB AT 0930UT.  THE P100 FLUX REACHED A PEAK OF 14PFU AT 25/2100UT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE UNSETTLED TO ACTIVE EARLY IN THE PERIOD.  MAJOR TO SEVERE STORM CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO BEGIN EARLY ON 27 JUN AS A RESULT OF THE X3 FLARE YESTERDAY.  STORM CONDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE THROUGH 28 JUN.  THE PARTICLE AND PCA EVENTS ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE TO DECLINE OVER THE NEXT 24 TO 48 HOURS.

sections.text: TO 27/2100Z:  SOLAR ACTIVITY WAS LOW.  REGION 7205 (N10W100) HAS QUIETLY CROSSED THE WEST LIMB.  REMAINING DISK REGIONS HAVE BEEN STABLE OR DECLINING.  REGION 7213 (N17E15) WAS ASSIGNED. A TYPE IV SWEEP WITH A POSSIBLE TYPE II (PRELIMINARY REPORT FROM CULGOORA) WERE OBSERVED WITH THE C2/SN FROM REGION 5209 (N11W01) AT 0005UT.

sections.text: LOW.  THERE IS A SLIGHT CHANCE OF AN ENERGETIC EVENT FROM DEPARTED REGION 7205.  OLD REGION 7186 (N11 L119) IS DUE BACK IN THE NEXT 24 HOURS.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY SUMMARY FROM 26/2100Z TO 27/2100Z:
sections.text: THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD WAS AT QUIET TO UNSETTLED LEVELS UNTIL 2038UT WHEN A SUDDEN IMPULSE (37 GAMMAS AT BOULDER) WAS OBSERVED.  THIS IMPULSE WAS EXPECTED FROM X3 FLARE OF 25 JUN. PROTON FLUXES CONTINUE TO DECLINE (CURRENT P10 FLUX IS 15PFU).  THE PCA EVENT ENDED AT 1000UT.

sections.title: GEOPHYSICAL ACTIVITY FORECAST:  THE GEOMAGNETIC FIELD IS
sections.text: EXPECTED TO BE ACTIVE TO MINOR STORM EARLY IN THE PERIOD.  THE FIELD IS EXPECTED TO RETURN TO UNSETTLED LEVELS BY 30 JUN. THE ENERGETIC PARTICLE EVENT, WHICH BEGAN ON 25 JUN, IS EXPECTED TO DECLINE BELOW EVENT THRESHOLDS WITHIN THE NEXT 12 HOURS.
